text: Alcohol in the Workplace 1 Alcohol in the Workplace Introduction Consuming alcohol– especially in excess – is linked to a number of negative outcomes: as a risk factor for diseases and health impacts; crime; road incidents; and for some, alcohol dependence. Alcohol is the single most used and abused drug in America. According to the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism also known as the NIAAA, nearly 14 million Americans or 1 in every 13 adults abuse alcohol. Several million more

adults engage in risky drinking patterns that could lead to alcohol problems. The costs to society in terms of lost productivity, health care costs, traffic accidents, and personal tragedies are staggering. Numerous studies and reports have been issued on the workplace costs of alcoholism and alcohol abuse. According to the National Business Group on Health, alcohol abuse costs employers an estimated $30 billion annually. Some of the effects that addiction has on employer- related costs include:

• Reduced business earnings due to decreased work productivity; • Criminal activities, such as stealing supplies or money; • Higher number of medical claim filings; • Higher number of workers’ compensation claim filings. No matter how minor a drinking problem may seem, alcohol abuse symptoms should not be ignored. Warning Signs There are various warning signs that can help detect potential problems with alcohol. While many signs are recognizable, others may be more difficult to identify. Also,

the severity of alcohol abuse may play a role in the warning signs a person exhibits. Some signs of alcohol problems may include the following: • Frequent tardiness; • Excessive use of sick leave; • Missed deadlines; • Unmet quotas; • Strained relationships with coworkers; • Bloodshot eyes; • Unsteady walking; • Tremors; Alcohol in the Workplace 2 • Sleeping on the clock; • Exhibiting signs of irritability and extreme mood swings; • Experiencing temporary blackouts or short-term memory loss; •

Choosing drinking over other responsibilities and obligations; • Making excuses for drinking such as to relax, deal with stress or feel normal. Short-Term Effects Even though people may not be abusing alcohol regularly, they can still experience its short-term effects on the mind and body. The liver can metabolize about one standard drink of alcohol per hour. However, this can vary depending on a number of factors, including the individual’s age, weight, liver function, and gender. Typically,

consuming more than one beverage per hour can lead to intoxication, raising an individual’s blood alcohol content with each drink. Common short-term effects of alcohol can include but not limited to: • Lowered self-consciousness, leading to poor social judgment; • Trouble concentrating; • Loss of coordination; • Loss of critical judgement; • Dulled perception, especially vision; • Mood swings; • Reduced core body temperature; • Raised blood pressure; • Passing out; • Vomiting. Long-Term Effects

Regular drinking can cause long-term damage to the body and there are a significant number of alcohol-related diseases and health problems caused by alcohol consumption. Chronic drinkers of alcohol are more likely to develop throat, mouth, or esophagus cancers. Breast cancer is also more common in women who drink excessively. One of the most common reasons of inflammatory damage is alcohol use. The liver is an organ which helps break down and remove harmful substances from your body, including

alcohol. Long-term alcohol use interferes with this process. Liver diseases are life-threatening and lead to toxins and waste buildup in your body. Another common result of long-term alcohol use is frontal lobe damage. Drinking makes it difficult for brain to create long-term memories. It also reduces ability to think Alcohol in the Workplace 3 clearly and make rational choices. Frontal lobe is an area of the brain that is responsible for emotional control, short-term memory, and judgement, in

addition to other vital roles. Chronic and severe alcohol abuse can also cause permanent brain damage. This can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a brain disorder that affects memory. People who drink frequently have a hard time fighting off bacteria and viruses and are more susceptible to illnesses like tuberculosis and pneumonia. Heavy drinking is one of the leading causes of cardiovascular disease. Circulatory system complications may include high blood pleasure, stroke, heart attack and

heart failure. Some people who drink heavily may develop a physical and emotional dependency on alcohol. Alcohol withdrawal can be difficult and life-threatening. Factors that Increase Alcohol Abuse The most common factors that increase the risk of alcohol abuse: Isolation. An isolated employee is more likely to consume alcohol as a result of boredom, loneliness or lack of social activities, events where the priority is focused on drinking or extended working hours or shift work. Interpersonal

aspects that increase the risk of an individual to have problems with alcohol. Aspects may include workplace relationships, bullying, harassment, and inadequate supervision. Poor working conditions such as hot and dangerous environments, inadequate job design and training, which may lead to low job satisfaction and/or work-related stress. Organizational change, restructure, job transfer or redundancy. How Alcohol Impacts the Workplace Alcohol use creates an unsafe work environment that increases

the risk of accidents resulting in injury or death particularly in occupations involving operating heavy machinery, driving vehicles, using hand tools or electric equipment. Individuals under the influence of alcohol can irreparably damage workplace relationships with those around them. The effects of alcohol can impact behavior, for example an individual affected by alcohol may act unprofessionally towards clients and customers; co-workers may feel uncomfortable working with an individual

experiencing 'hangover' effects of alcohol. Alcohol in the Workplace 4 Lower workplace productivity is another consequence of alcohol use, caused by short-term absence; lower quality and quantity of work due to poor decision making; disruption to operations; and co-workers covering for alcohol-affected employees. Alcohol use impacts workplace economy with long-term alcohol-related burden, attributed to compensation and employer liabilities; loss of skills and employees; and the related costs of

replacement and training new employees. Suspicion of Alcohol Abuse in the Workplace Everyone is entitled to feel safe in the workplace. We spend as much time at work as we do at home with our families, so expecting a work environment that is free from the effects of alcohol is a given. We go to our jobs each day to produce goods or services and to earn an honest living, and that is hindered when a coworker or boss is coming to work intoxicated. Some of the steps that can be taken in a situation

where a coworker seems to be under the influence is to refer to your company’s manual or employee handbook. There is usually an official procedure in place with direction on what to do in situations like this. One approach is to alert your manager or supervisor to the fact that you are aware of an employee who is using alcohol during work. A supervisor can take the appropriate actions to handle the situation, although you may be required to speak to human resources or an upper-level manager

about the incident. Let your manager know if you prefer to remain anonymous. Another way is to talk to the human resources and report the incident. You may have to fill out a report of your observations as to why you believe a co-worker might be under influence. Last recommendation is to avoid confronting the employee on your own or telling other co-workers about the situation. Doing so will only create the potential for danger and the spreading of rumors. Your co-workers likely cannot do

anything more than you can to resolve the situation anyway, so it is best to tell only management and human resources. Recommendations to Lower the Risk of Drinking The following recommendations can help keep your drinking at low risk and manage high risk situations. • Avoid drinking situations by going to places where alcohol is not served, like the movies, parks or beaches. If you drink because you are bored or stressed, a walk or playing a sport may help. Alcohol in the Workplace 5 • Slow

down your drinking. A drink can be enjoyed just as much, if not more, if you drink slowly. • Avoid drinking. When you go out take a non-alcoholic beverage with you. • Practice saying no. It may be difficult at first, but you will be surprised how quickly you can become comfortable to saying ‘no’ and others around you will accept your decision. Employee Assistance Programs Many workplaces sponsor Employee Assistance Programs (EAPs) that offer short-term counseling and/or assistance in linking

employees with alcohol problems to local treatment resources, including peer support and/or recovery groups. Contact your Human Resources Department to find out if your company offers an EAP. The Employee Assistance Program fulfills four main roles within a company, which are • Employee education and training; • Confidential employee record-keeping; • Alcohol treatment counseling; • Assistance with accessing medical treatment services. If an alcohol addiction problem gets to the point where

individual needs to take a leave of absence, it is always best to go through an employer’s EAP when possible. It is important that an employee, and the EAP representative reach an understanding as to what treatment services are needed to enable a person to work at the expected productivity levels that their job requires. This means the individual will need to be as honest and forthcoming as possible with the EAP representative so the necessary arrangements can be made. Once treatment approach is

selected, the EAP representative will draw up a treatment plan that spells out the conditions surrounding rehabilitation process. These conditions will include any work leaves or modified work schedules as well as the types of services that will be received while away from work. The treatment plan should also include a confidentiality section that states any information discussed during meetings with an EAP representative remains private. Part of the treatment planning stage involves determining

what conditions must be met for an individual to continue to work for the employer, if possible. These conditions may be listed on the actual treatment plan or a separate return-to-work agreement that spells out these conditions in detail. The Adults with Disabilities Act or ADA and the Family and Medical Leave Act, known as FMLA are two federal laws that protect employee rights within the workplace. ADA provisions prohibit employers from discriminating against employees who have known Alcohol

in the Workplace 6 disabilities. As alcohol addiction is classified as a medical condition, ADA provisions apply for someone who struggles with an alcohol addiction. ADA laws work to ensure employees seeking help with alcohol problems can receive the needed attention and services provided through an employer’s EAP. FAA Alcohol Testing Program The aviation industry can be considered as one of the most highly regulated sectors and has random testing for alcohol as required in accordance with

regulations 14 CFR 120 and 49 CFR 40 to meet Department of Transportation annual testing requirements. In addition, if someone is suspected of being under the influence a random test may be required by a Supervisor or HR that has been properly trained and delegated to make such a decision. Alcohol testing regulations are strictly imposed to all safety-sensitive employees in the aviation industry to ensure that every employee is fit to perform his duties. FAA-mandated alcohol testing program

includes the following rules: • No one should be hired or transferred to a safety-sensitive job without having to undergo a pre-employment alcohol test and must receive a negative test result. • Employees or applicants that are about to take a position for any safety-sensitive function should be checked if they have previously tested positive or have refused to undergo an alcohol test from their previous employers. • Make sure that employees will undergo random testing, which should be conducted

at a minimum rate of 10% for alcohol as directed by the division of FAA Drug and Alcohol Abatement. Refusal of an Alcohol Test As a result of an employee refusing to take an alcohol test the following will occur: • Immediate removal from the safety-sensitive duties; • Revocation of FAA certificates and ratings held; • Typically, probation or termination of employment. Employers are required to report to the FAA’s Federal Air Surgeon all employees who refuse to submit to alcohol testing. This is

applicable to any safety-sensitive employee or an employee who holds a repairman or mechanic certificate in accordance with regulations 14 CFR 65. Returning to Work After a Violation Employees cannot return to their safety-sensitive functions after a refusal or positive alcohol test without the following taking place: Alcohol in the Workplace 7 • Employers must provide the employee a list of Substance Abuse Professionals also known as an SAP. Once the employee has chosen an SAP, a face-to-face

evaluation will be set up. The SAP will be able to provide a complete written report that includes the recommended education and treatment plan, and the content of the evaluation. • After undergoing treatment, the SAP needs to perform a re-evaluation to assess if the employee has successfully completed required education and treatment plan. The SAP will then write a report to the employer indicating the findings from the re-evaluation. • Prior to the employee returning to his safety-sensitive

position, he needs to undergo a return-to-duty alcohol test under the direct observation of an authorized professional of the clinic that conducts alcohol testing. The employee undergoing testing must produce a verified negative breath-alcohol test result. If a test is positive this will result in additional provisions and a lengthy path to regaining certifications and working in a safety-sensitive position once again, if ever at all. • If an employee can overcome these adversities, future
alcohol testing will be done under direct supervision as directed by an SAP.
